DOC.HEAD: Planes Bring Wounded Servicemen Back From Panama
Eds: UPDATES throughout with second plane arriving, details, updated casualty count, third plane expected, other details; no pickup.
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two transport planes flew 108 servicemen wounded in the U.S. invasion of Panama to military hospitals Wednesday, but three were dead on arrival and another died later, officials said. The first C-141 landed at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio at 11:37 a.m. with 43 soldiers aboard, including the three dead and the one who died shortly after arrival. The 39 wounded were taken to Wilford Hall Medical Center at adjacent Lackland Air Force Base, said Lt. Dave Ebner, a spokesman at Kelly. Some were well enough to take buses, and others were taken by ambulance, said Lackland spokeswoman Dolores Schroeder. The second C-141 arrived at Kelly around 5:30 p.m. with 65 soldiers with ``serious to very critical'' injuries, said Lt. Col. Johnny Whitaker, another Lackland spokesman. ``The biggest and the most extensive injuries are gunshot-type wounds, schrapnel-type wounds, leg wounds, broken bones, this sort of thing,'' Whitaker said. Forty-one of the soldiers on the second flight were taken across town to Brooke Army Medical Center, Whitaker said. The rest went to Wilford Hall. Another transport was expected later Wednesday, said Whitaker, who was unsure how many wounded would be aboard. Kelly officials were told their base would be the sole reception point for wounded from Panama. Pentagon officials said 15 U.S. servicemen and a female civilian dependent were killed, one serviceman was missing and more than 100 were wounded.
